Find an enormous empty room with a beautifully creepy chair, grab a kettle bell and get to work. This was a nice recovery chain after lots of squats yesterday. A chain is slightly different than a complex in that you do one of each move sequentially for multiple rounds, rather than multiple reps of each move. Chains a excellent for a recovery day as you pump blood and work through ranges of motion while still allowing muscles to recover after a hard lift.
Be smart about your training. Recover faster and more effectively. Stay Driven. @performixdriven

Nothing motivates me like healthy shoulders !!!💪🏻💪🏻💪🏻 Use this 4 exercise shoulder prep before your next upper body workout.
I did this before training yesterday and felt amazing! My cranky left shoulder didn't bother me and my chest really opened up.
I used 12lb DBs for 8 reps of each exercise. You don't need to go heavy. This complex focuses on activating upper back.. Scapular retractors, rear deltoids, triceps (primarily the superior insertion responsible for shoulder extension. Think L seat hold) It also opens up your anterior chain primarily pec and pec minor.
These are all controlled movements. If you can't hold each position for a full second the weight is too heavy!
1) Rocket man raise - keep your abs tight and focus on lifting through your shoulders, NOT pulling you chest off the bench. This focus is shoulder extension not thoracic extension ( which is often used as a compensatory motion if shoulder mobility or stability are inadequate ). Palms face up. Keep your arms straight. You will feel your lats and triceps fire!
2) Retraction to kick back - same body position as above. Retract scapular, squeezing shoulder blades together as you extend your arms. Triceps and upper back should be screaming at you.
3) W fly - arms bent at 90 degrees. Using a reverse fly motion lift and pause at the top. This move is less about retraction and more focused on horizontal abduction firing the posterior delts and rhomboids.
4) Stretch fly - control the DBs down to a stretched position at the bottom of the fly. Hang out here for a few seconds. Keep you hands even with your shoulders, i.e. Making a T.. You can experiment with lowering them slightly above your shoulders making a wide Y to increase stretch to the pec minor which is notoriously tight.
Do 1 set or 8 as part of your upper body warm up.
Do 2-3 sets or 8-10 as a finisher pump on your upper body day.
Have an awesome day!!!!

ARMS 💪🏻 My arms have never been a strong point of my physique, so I'm putting some extra work in this summer. Big Bang compound moves like chin ups and dips are a must for growth, but my lats and delts often take over for my arms here. So including some isolation work is going to be necessary too.
I also get bored as heck doing 4x10s of straight sets, especially for single joint moves, so I mix up variations in a complex or Tri Set to keep the volume up.
Check out all 3 videos-
Program Rx
Video 1
Tall kneeling curl Complex (this on is from Anarchy Abs)
Pronated curl x5
Supinated curl x 5
Hammer curl x 5
Hammer curl to press x 5 (2x through is 1 round, the video is the last half of my second round) ----------------------- Video 2
Triceps complex (This one I learned from @jlifting and still love for a high volume set)
Skull crusher x 5
Rolling press x 5
Close grip press x 5
(3x through is 1 round)
Do 1 round of biceps followed by 1 round of triceps. Rest 90 seconds. Repeat for 2-3 rounds.
In the tall kneeling position, squeeze your abs and glutes, you may sway a little like I am in the video, but try to minimize body movement. ------------------------ Video 3
Incline bench Tri Set
A) kickbacks x 10-12
B) straight arm kick backs x 10-12
C) spider curl x 10-12
That's 1 round. Rest 60 seconds. Do 3 rounds.
The kickbacks (both straight and bent) get your upper back involved too, think retraction. Also, they work the long head of the tricep which inserts into your scapula, crossing the shoulder joint and is (partly) responsible for shoulder extension, an often overlooked function of the triceps. Think L sit or reverse plank!
Start with light weights and get through all the reps. Do this 2x week for 3-4 weeks.

'We will not be stopped by failure, we will not be rushed or distracted by external noise. We will chisel and peg away at the obstacle until it is gone. Resistance is futile.' - This is a quote from The Obstacle is the Way by Ryan Holiday. It is in reference to General Grant's outlook and tactics during the Civil War- Grant tried one unsuccessful tactic after the next until an untested and incredibly risky maneuver gave him the advantage that would eventually help win the war.
•
Failure is the only way true innovation is achieved. Failure is never failure until you stop trying. Fail often. Fail hard. Never give up. @performixdriven

The moment you feel your body giving up, hold on for one more second.. push out one more rep.. throw one more punch. Your body will give in long before your mind, don't let it. Your mind has the extraordinary power to overcome fatigue and block out pain. It's the final seconds and reps in any set that mean the most- they build physical strength and temper mental toughness. Fight for your ''one more' today! Stay Driven @performixdriven

Total Body Stability Circuit
3 moves will challenge your balance, core and cardio.
Program Rx
As a warm up do 2-3 rounds 40 seconds work / 20 seconds rest.
As a finisher or workout do 3-5 rounds 45 seconds work / 15 seconds rest.
Split stance 2 DB row L
Split stance 2 DB row R
Split stance switch
SL burpee - Push up T fly L
SL burpee - Push up T fly R
Hollow DB OH press
Coaching cues
DB weight - I used 20lb in the video. Keep DB weight light and focus on balance and body position.
Row - Torso angle is inline with back leg. Front knee is directly over your ankle. Keep chest out shoulders back posture and squeeze each rep at the top.
Split switch - Torso is vertical. Minimal vertical movement on the jump. Stick each switch, own the position for a second before the next switch.
Burpee - Don’t rush. Hit each position. Wider stance with the feet will help balance for the T fly.
Hollow Press - Control both directions. Your lats will fire similar to an ab rollout. Maintaining hollow position in the torso is crucial. Bend your knees if you have to but keep you low back pressed against the floor.
Have fun with this and have an awesome day!
Gear - @reebok

Tricep Torture
Add this super set to the end of your upper body workout. The complex is a mechanical drop set - this means the moves get 'easier' mechanically allowing you to continue through the long set as if you were using a lighter weight for each move.

Do 6-8 reps of each move
1) Skull crusher - Keep upper arm vertical
2) JM Press - elbows move forward towards the side of your rib cage, back of your hands come to the front of your shoulders.
3) Close grip press - Keep elbows close to side, bar lands just below chest.
Farmers carry - use 2 heavy KBs
Walk 100 feet. Think about walking tall and keeping a little tension behind your shoulders and in your triceps.
Do 3-4 rounds
Rest 30-60s between sets

The word strength has many definitions. Strength can be defined as the ability to move an object or stop and object from moving. Absolute strength (moving an external load) vs relative strength ( ability to move your own body weight). Maximum strength ( heaviest bench or squat) vs strength endurance ( squatting for 20+ reps) . Mental strength vs physical strength.
Whatever the definition, each one of us has an individual relationship with the word and how it resonates in our life.
You all have strength.
Stay Strong. Speer Strength.
Have an awesome day!

Clean and press x 5,3,2 with a sprint between each ladder rung.
We did 5 rounds and added 20 decline sit-ups in the sand between each ladder set.
You can use any implement for this workout- rock, barbell, kettlebells, sand bags.

By adding an explosive element to the basic push-up, you amplify the benefits. Move into a prone position on the floor, supporting your weight on your hands and toes. Your arms should be fully extended with the hands around shoulder width. Keep your body straight throughout the movement. This will be your starting position. Descend by flexing at the elbow, lowering your chest towards the ground. At the bottom, reverse the motion by pushing yourself up through elbow extension as quickly as possible. Attempt to push your upper body up until your hands leave the ground. Return to the starting position and repeat the exercise. For added difficulty, add claps into the movement while you are air borne.

These two moves will give your shoulders and upper back the attention that they need.
PUSH-UP WITH SQUEEZE
4 sets of 8-10 reps, with squeeze at the top. As you get to the top of the press, squeeze your elbows toward each other, trying to rotate in and bring your elbows in toward the center of your body.
FARMER'S CARRY
4 sets of 100 feet. You can use kettlebells, dumbbells, or whatever other weight you have, but the key is to use something with some substantial weight. Walk about 100 feet, or whatever your gym space allows, keeping that same tall posture the whole time. Then, just set the weights down at the end of the walk.

This workout combines balance, power and abs. Keep each move crisp, focus on maintaining control in the start (and finish) position of each move.
This means athletic posture in the starting position of both jump variations - rigid torso (abs tight), arms extended behind the hips, tension in your upper back.
On the push up and plank walk keep your glutes tight and hips tucked. Always focusing on quality over quantity.
You'll be working for 30 seconds per move (30s each leg on the jumps) and rest for 15. Do 3-5 rounds.
1) Bench jump to single foot landing
2) Feet elevated push up knee drive
3) Plyo step up
4) Extended plank walk up with knee drive

Back Attack!
A strong back in essential for building a strong, functional physique.
Compound sets are basically super-sets or tri-sets that focus on competitive or synergistic muscle groups - chest and tris, back and biceps. They allow you to combine a strength, hypertrophy and endurance in one set. I LOVE using compound sets for back work because of the added benefit of grip strength.
Add this compound tri-set into you next upper body or back focus workout. The rotational element and bar placement on the inverted rows also gives your biceps a extra hit.
Program Rx
Ring Pull x 6
Rotational Single arm row x 8
Reverse grip Inverted row x 12-15
Do 3 rounds
Rest 10-20s between exercises
Rest 90s - 2min between sets

Coaching cues * Do chin ups if you are using a bar * If you can do 10 BW chins, add weight to make 6 reps challenging * Control the motion in the rotational row. Go as heavy as you can still allowing a squeeze for a full second at the top *You can use DB or KB for the row * Set your position on the inverted rows so the bar hits just above your nipple line. You will feel your grip and biceps working. This position forces more elbow flexion in the supinate grip similar to a curl. ( this is a variation, traditionally I would say pull the bar just under your nipple line for greater lat activation)
Have fun with this and have an awesome day!!!

Split Squat Finisher!
This one will smoke your glutes and quads, challenge you lateral trunk stability (obliques), hip and shoulder stability.. and it's a great fat burning finisher for leg day!
Keep your abs tight! You will know when you lose core tension, because you'll lean to the side and lose balance. Control the motion both up and down. Start with a very light dumbbell and work up once you can complete the entire sequence.
Here it is-- Over head split squat x 5
Racked split squat x 5
Side split squat x 5
Body weight split squat x 5 ( add plyo for extra challenge)
Do the entire sequence Right side
Rest 20 seconds
Do left side
Rest 20 seconds
Do 4-5 rounds!

Hello Instagram! How are your hollow rocks coming?!?! Here is a 3 step progression to help you reach you hollow rock goals!
Vid1 : hollow kick out- pull your shoulder blades off the floor, pull your knees above your hips, extend legs to hollow position, hold 1 sec and release.
Vid 2: modified hollow rock- pull into hollow body position with you hands reaching to your feet. Bring your knees into a bent knee hollow position. Rock and extend arms over when you can, keeping hollow position.
Vid 3: Hollow rock baby!
Program Suggestions:
3 sets of 5 kick outs
3 sets of 10 modified rocks
2 sets of 10 rocks, adding 4 each day.
Hope this gives your training a little extra kick!

Wake up your body and mind with this superset!
This set will give you a full body mobility warmup and wake up your nervous system and vestibular system ( your balance control center). The bridge walk outs are an amazing stretch for you anterior truck ( abs and hip flexors). The will also challenge balance front to back, which is often over looked as we think of balance as standing or jumping on one leg. * push your knees forward slightly as you bend back, keeping your weight over your feet.
The jump to pull up challenges hand eye coordination which wakes up your nervous system and fires your grip reflex for some extra shoulder and rotator cuff activation. * If you can't do pull ups, jump, catch and hang for 3 seconds. Be sure to switch your grip on each jump.
Do 1-2 sets of 5 as part of your warm up and let me know how you feel!

Strength and Power EMOM!
Dead lifts and overhead movements are one of my favorite pairings. This one builds strength with the dead lift and total body power with the jerk. The metabolic hit is high so be prepared for a Saturday Sweat Sesh!
Here it is-
EMOM - 18 minutes
Minute 1 - 6 dead lifts
Minute 2 - 6 Jerks right side
Minute 3 - 6 Jerks left side
Repeat for 6 rounds
Go on the moderate/heavier side for these. It's a 6x6(x6), I used 275lb for DLs and 32kg for jerks. That's about 70% of a heavy single (not max) on the DL, and a weight you can strict press for 5 reps on the jerk. *My hips are scooping forward more than I'd like on the jerks. Ideally hips remain under the torso and don't push forward during the initiation of the upward motion.
Have an awesome Saturday!!!

My man Clinton gave me a cocoa dance lesson and about 3 minutes in my shoulders and abs were smoked. These guys typically do 30-40min sessions, that's crazy endurance!
The Fond Doux Plantation & Resort was originally a cocoa bean and banana plantation. When the current owners took it over, they had no plans of turning into a hotel. The economy on the island began to shift towards tourism, so one cottage at a time the plantation slowly grew into a working hotel. The coolest part is that it is still a working cocoa plantation. The beans are picked all over the property then dried and danced on right-smack in the center courtyard of the hotel. Each individual bean is then shelled by hand!
Taking the opportunity to experience part of the preparation was super cool and definitely gave me a new perspective on how much work goes into making every bar of chocolate — that I so casually unwrap to take down as a treat.
Have an awesome Thursday everyone!

This is one of my favorite upper body / anti-rotation supersets. 💪🏻 Both the push up and the row challenge anti-rotation of the core. Some things to pay attention to... * Keep the KB handle off the floor. Working to keep it steady adds a shoulder stability element. * As you reach the top of the push Up, drive your hand hard into the bell by protracting your shoulder (pushing your torso away from the floor) * Pause for 1 second in both the top and bottom positions. Rush will negate the stability challenge. * Keep you hips and shoulders square to the floor, that's the anti- rotation element. * Same holds true for the rows, keep shoulders and hips squared and don't rush the reps.
Do 4-5 sets
6 push ups on each arm
12 rows on each arm

Loosen up.
Tightness in your thoracic spine, the mid and upper back area, can have many causes. These 5 moves will mobilize and stretch you upper back. If tightness or pain is chronic always get it checked out by a professional.
Here we go... 1) Thoracic extension on the foam roller. Place your shoulder blades in the top of the roller. Support your head with your hands and keep your elbows pointing up, not out. Keep some tension in your abs, don't let your ribs pop up and your low back arch. Do 5 extensions in that spot them move 2 inches about and 2 inches below and do the same.
2) Kneeling thoracic rotation. Set up like a child's pose with your torso at 30-45 degrees. Thread right arm through your left arm and knee trying to get you right shoulder to the floor. Hold the stretch for 5 seconds then rotate your right arm up to the ceiling. Do 6-8 on each side.
3) Cat cow. Round your back by pushing through your shoulders and tucking your hips then arch your back and look up gently while still push through your shoulders. Do 10.
4) Scapular push ups. Same set up as the cat cow. Push your torso to the floor by squeezing your shoulder blades together then push you torso away from the floor be separating your shoulder blades. Keep you back straight. Do 10.
5) Side lying thoracic rotation. Set up on your side with bottom leg straight and top leg bent 90 degrees with knee at hip level. Open your top arm over the top making an arch. The goal it to eventually get the back of your shoulder to the floor, not crank your arm down. Breath out gently as you reach the stretch position. Do 8 each side.
Hopefully this will loosen you up. Do these in the morning or before you workout.

Constant Tension Pec Pump💪🏻 Kettle bells are not renowned in the world of chesticular development, but this Tri-set is sure to give your pecs the perfect pump for the Friday night club scene 😜

The focus is to keep tension in your chest, hence the name, constant tension. Break down more muscle fibers and pull fluid into your pecs.
Program Rx
1) See Saw Floor Press x 10-12 each arm
2) Crush Press x 12-15
3) Wide Grip Tension Push Ups x 12-15
Minimal rest between exercises
60-90 seconds rest between sets
Coaching cues
See Saw Floor Press- Move the bells in a reciprocating motion, never locking arms at the top and never letting your elbows touch the floor. Don't rush the movement.
Crush Press- Keep you fingers off the bell, hold it by squeezing in, or crushing the bell as the name implies. Try to squeeze juice out of that bell like an orange! At the top of the movement, squeeze you elbow (and upper arms) together, don't try to lock your arms out.
Wide Grip Tension Push Ups- Set a wider that shoulder width grip. Stretch as far as you can in the bottom position with out losing Tension, and again don't lock your arms in the top position.
Careful with the bells on the hard wood floors 😬

Kettlebell Shoudler Stability Complex
I finished my workout with a few rounds of this KB complex. Pushing the shoulder stability with increasing external loads in a variety of positions. I should also add I've been working with @lukemotiv and using

Shoulder Strength and Stability Sequence. (Gotta love that alliteration)
The first move is an arm bar. The focus is scapular and shoulder stability so don't let your shoulder roll forward, keep it pulled back. You should feel the inside edge of your scapula firing, along with your posterior shoulder. Hold this arm bar for 20-30 seconds.
Then roll to Turkish get up position and work your way through the sequence. It's about 60s of time under tension for your shoulder so you don't need a super heavy weight. Focus is on control, especially in the eccentric part of the press.
Do 2-4 sets on each side, alternating sides, as an excellent warm up for upper body day.
Have fun with this and have an awesome day!!

Keep the Devil off your shoulder with Halos!
Halos serve as an outstanding warm up with a two fold purpose: •Warm up and mobilize the shoulders in the natural rotational motion of the shoulder's ball and socket joint type. •Challenge hip stability, trunk stability, and balance in with different variations.
A couple examples or program application would be: •Warm up for a unilateral lower body lifts like lunges or step ups with a unilateral halo position (half kneeling, split stance or split squat). This will fire up your glutes and hip stabilizers as well as you reinforce your pelvis into the proper, neutral position. •Warm up for an overhead press with a tall kneeling or standing halo. This position warms up the shoulders and emphasizes keeping the ribs down and abs tight trunk position as the arms travel overhead, same position you're working for in the press.
In order of the video:
1) Tall Kneeling
2) Standing
3) Half kneeling
4) Split Stance
5) Split Squat (my back knee should be 2-3" lower)

Dumbbell Core Circuit - Classic moves with a twist. This circuit challenges abs, lats, shoulder stability and scapular movement and stability.
Work any of these moves into your training today or string then all together in a circuit.
Program Rx:
Do each move for 40s, rest 20.
Do 3-5 rounds.
Don't count reps. Focus on form and control not numbers with this one.
Coaching cues: 💪🏻Start with light DBs and work up. I used 15lb and that was plenty. 💪🏻Bird dog renegade row - This is very challenging. It's ok if your weight shifts slightly over your down arm. Keep your hips squared up to the floor and your knee under your hip, not out to the side. Take it slow. Adjust foot and hand position for balance. 💪🏻Hollow body angel - like a snow angel for abs. This works your pecs, shoulders and lats too. Think about pulling your arms in towards your spine while pushing your hands up (against gravity) with your chest and lats. You don't want full retraction of the scaps, just enough tension to keep them from sliding out to the side or up towards your ears. Control the motion, don't rush this one. 💪🏻T plank to side press - drive the lower arm hard into the DB, pushing your torso away from the floor. On the side press think about pulling your elbow behind your torso with you lat. Open your chest, without letting your ribs pop out. Try to create a stretch in the your pec/ pec minor ( depending on how tight you are) and tension on the medial edge (closest to the spine) of your scapula). 💪🏻Hollow scissor w DB - Keep your biceps by your ears in the open position. Control the motion both directions. 💪🏻Overhead Rocks - classic rock with an extra hit for the lats and abs.

MINDSET MONDAY
You will face challenges this week, that’s life. Imagine how under stimulating and unfulfilling life would be with out challenges to overcome. That in itself is enough to to be grateful for each and every challenge that you encounter. Some challenges are seemingly not very demanding, other obstacles appear monumentous at first glance. Your mindset as you approach each and every challenge dictates not only the external outcome, but more importantly your internal reaction to that outcome, and even more importantly- your adaptation and growth during the process which then leads to your ability to handle more demanding challenges in the future. Right from the start look for the positive in the situation, it may not be staring you in the face, give it a minute, take a breath, look through the eyes of POSITIVE PERSPECTIVE and ask yourself:

1) What will I learn/gain/improve upon having overcome this challenge? (GROW)
2) How will that increase my ability to be of service to others? (GIVE)

Be honest and specific in you answers. Realize from the get go this process will not be easy but will be worth it. Remember that you are worth it! Have an awesome Monday and challenging and rewarding week!

My current favorite press variation 💪🏻
I started playing around with open hand KB pressing as I thought it would have a more specific transfer to the acro yoga I've been getting into. I added the flip between each press, it's a whole new ball game.
•
There is a serious hand-eye coordination component, this makes the lift fun and addicting on a skill development level.
•
The core and lat demand is real, in fact I don't think I've done another press variation where I actually feel my lats and obliques work so hard. This may be due to the velocity and positional variation of the bell during the catch and the lack of grip tension during the press.
•
I did 5 sets of 3 on each arm with a 28kg bell, it was a challenging weight. I can do 8 strict 2KB presses at this weight for reference.
•
This flip to open hand press is an advanced move so practice open hand pressing for reps with a light bell first, then practice the flip and catch, then put the two moves together.
•

Use this split stance complex as a warm up or part of your total body workout! 💪🏻 Here it is -

Coaching cues
* Split stance set up is crucial. Front foot flat, back foot on ball of foot. * Squeeze your glute on the back leg, this helps tuck you hips and maintain a stable neutral pelvis.

As a warm up do 2 sets in each side with a light/ medium bell.
As a part of your total body workout do 3-4 sets with a medium/ heavy bell. The halos will be your limiting factor for loading in this complex.

Stretch it Out.
Try these 3 upper body stretches, they are especially useful after calisthenics and bar workouts with a heavy dose of hanging, pull up and push up variations.
The key to these is always being active in the stretch and using your breath - meaning pushing or pulling yourself into the position, not falling into with your body weight.
In the first stretch which hits the entire side of your body (lats, obliques, lateral hips), I am pushing with my lower arm and more importantly pulling my hips away from the bar using my obliques on the opposite side to contract and push my hips away. I'll take 5-10 slow deep breathes, adjust my feet slightly to increase the range of the stretch and repeat. (I shortened the breathing and stretch time for the video). For the pec and forearm/wrist stretch. I pull myself into position with control, breath I the stretch position, then actively push myself out of the stretch with the muscles I'm stretching, then pull myself back into the stretched position.
Start with 5 sets of 5 breaths per stretch, work you way up to 10 sets of 10 breaths per stretch. That means in a row with the the only 'break' being when you adjust the stretch at the end of the breathing sets.
This is work, not lazy stretching.
Your body will thank you!
Have fun with this and have an awesome day!

Growing up I was a skinny kid with big ears that stuck straight out from my head and face full of acne. Outside of gymnastics, I didn't have much confidence in myself. My entire life I have had a very difficult time expressing my emotions, both positive and negative. I held in all my angst, uncertainty and lack of confidence. I figured it would get better or go away at some point. I put most of my value as a person on how I looked from a very young age and thought if I 'looked normal' I would change and become a 'better person' and people would like me more.
I grew my hair out to cover my ears and put on 45 lbs of muscle my first two years of college. I was pole vaulting for a D1 school and president of my fraternity.. I was still not confident in myself as a person. My identity was based on 'what I did' rather that 'who I was'. I had surgery to 'fix' my ears when I was 24 years old. Still, much of my mid 20s I was floating around, getting by with random jobs until I found training and realized I could coach, teach and motivate for a career. Thank God for that. Purpose. Sure my physical appearance had changed, and sure it probably helped in an industry largely based on aesthetics. But more importantly, I had found a purpose. Loosely defined at that point, but I knew I loved coaching and changing lives and now had an opportunity to do so through fitness.
I don't share that part of my life very often, and I wish I did more.
I am still working everyday not to fall back into old patterns, self doubt, lack of confidence, beating myself up over my insecurities. Work in progress.
Where ever you are right now is exactly where you are supposed to be. That doesn't mean you have to stay there. We all have the power with in us to transform- physically, mentally, spiritually.
We all have insecurities and imperfections. That's what makes us human. We have all gone through periods in our life that we wish would end sooner than later.
Whatever you've been through in your life made you who you are today. And today you are f*cking awesome! Don't forget that.
It's amazing how far fitness can takes us. How building your body, can help build your mind. So today, let's all try to go that extra mile and push ourselves to grow.
The struggle you are in today is developing the strength you need for tomorrow. 👊🏻

Time to mix it up with a new dumbbell complex👊🏻 Do this as a quick total body workout or program as a warm up using lighter weights or a finisher using heavier weights. I used 35lb DBs in the video.
Program Rx -
8x DB clean to alternating lunge
10x Batwing row ( ea arm, alternate)
12x Single leg burpee to dead lift (6 ea, don't alternate)
Do 4 rounds
Rest 90s between rounds
Coaching cues * DB clean is an explosive hip hinge like a KB swing. Your arms and shoulders will feel it, but make sure the power and movement comes from your hips, not your arms. Keep abs tight at the top to prevent arching the lower back.
* Batwing row is a favorite for the isometric elements in upper back, spinal extensors and core. Focus on keeping tension in the up arm and controlling the movement in both directions. * Be sure to bend your knee enough on the down leg during the deadlift to maintain proper back position (neutral spine). Have fun with this one and have an awesome day!!!

Ankle mobility is crucial for maintaining proper technique in squatting, jumping, running. Immobile ankles are also a major cause of hip and knee pain due to over compensation.

Here is a nice 3 step series to prep the ankles.

1) foot roll x 10 - mobilizing the foot / ankle in plantar flexion (pointing the toe) and inversion and eversion ( turning the foot in and out) is often over looked when mobilizing the ankle. You should feel a nice stretch from the top of your ankle down the side of your foot.

2- Calve stretch x 20 sec - lengthening the musculature and soft tissue of the calf ( gastroc and soleus ) will allow for greater range in dorsi flexion. If you bend your knee slightly you will enhance the stretch in your soleus, the lower part of your calf.

3 - knee push - keep your heel on the floor and push your knee towards the wall. At minimum your knee should be able to touch the wall with your toe 4 inches away from the wall.

This takes less than 1 minute per foot. I have all my clients so this everyday as part of their warm up.

Have fun!!!

Suns Out, Scaps Out 🌞💪🏻 Building your body to handle the demands of bar work such as pull ups, muscle ups, levers and more advanced maneuvers requires more than big lats and Biceps. In fact, the big muscles are the easiest develop. Not spending the time to develop your connective tissue, grip strength and scapular strength and control will lead to injury and skill set backs.
These moves will help develop scapular strength and control.
1) Decline scap shrugs and circles

2) Feet elevated scap shrugs and circles (progression) - work protraction (pushing forward) retraction ( pulling backward) elevation (shrugging) depression (pulling scaps down towards your hips). Start with the shrugs (forward backward) and work up to the full circle.
3) Hanging scap shrug - this move works elevation and depression on the scapular. It's much more challenging than the push up position, but critical to building strength and keeping shoulders healthy.
Start with 2 arms. Work up to 1 arm. You can see I have less control on my left arm, so I'll rest my feet on the ground for stability and weight assistance.
Spend 15 minutes a day working these drills before you workout.
Doing the little things will keep you healthy and progress you faster than jumping right into the high flying acts. Have fun with this and have an awesome Tuesday!

I HATE working out alone.

Yes, sometimes I have to, and I do it.

We all have different personalities, brain chemistry, training experience... we are all in a different space in our ‘fitness journey’. We all have different perspectives and reactions to our environments. That’s what makes you.. you! Don’t trade your individuality for anything, you are you, embrace every little bit of you!

Back to my point- It’s about figuring out what works for you, implementing the actions into your life, sticking with them for long enough that they be come habits.

This is not an excuse to be lazy and say ‘I don’t really LIKE working out, I guess it’s not for me’...NO! Always strive to be the best version of you- you have to be honest with yourself about what that means. Some days are a struggle, some days you’re walking on clouds, that’s life- take the next step and keep moving forward.

I’m an introvert at heart, I need my alone time to recover, reflect and rest. My actions and creative processes are optimized when I am in a stimulating environment- meaning I watch, I listen, I bounce ideas, I talk things out, I move, I feel the energy around me and it amps me up. My workouts are always better when I train with someone or in a group- that’s me, period. Yes, I will workout alone, and sometimes I use it as (mental) recovery and reflection time, but when I want to go hard I need a stimulating, engaging environment. Throw a competition in the mix and I’m full throttle ahead.

My point is figure out how YOU best think, learn, train and recover- embrace it- make it work for you!

Don’t beat yourself up over not being the guy who trains at 330am, that sure as heck ain’t me, that’s ok. Find a workout partner, or an accountability group or an at home DVD series. Figure out what time of day you feel the best and has the least interruptions and arrange your schedule (as best you can within reality of your situation). The effort and financial resources you put in on the front end will eventually come back 10 fold in success because you’ll actually be taking the action necessary to succeed, not half-assing things wishing you ‘liked working out alone’. Own you. No one else can.

Upper Body and Abs EMOM

Program Rx
Do each on the minute
Do 5 rounds
1) Floor press x10 and Push ups on DBs x 10
2) Pull ups - AMRAP in 30sec
3) TRX row x 15
4) Slams x 10
5) Russian Twist x 20

The first 3 moves get you a nice pump. Push through and hit your reps. Slams and twists hit your core as well as lats, arms and cardio. Think power on the slams- don't rush through the set but hit each rep as hard as you can. Use a heavy ball.
Have fun with this and have an awesome afternoon!

A single light-to-medium dumbbell is all you need to light your core and chest on fire 🔥This circuit trains you to hold tension in your trunk while moving your extremities, which is the foundation for most athletic movement. Perform the exercises below in the order listed with 30 seconds of work for each move and 15 seconds of rest between moves.

1. Dumbbell kneeling crush press out

2. Dumbbell bent-over crush row

3. Dumbbell hollow-body hold crush pull over

4. Dumbbell crush hollow-body rock

That's 1 round. Rest for 60 seconds. Repeat for 2 to 3 rounds.

The spring sun is finally here, for many of us that means running weather. Along with the increase in running volume often comes increased tightness in calves, hamstrings and hips. Preparing your joints and muscles before you run can help keep you running strong and pain free.
This is an 8 move warm up circuit to prep your ankles and hips for your run.
1) Ankle rolls - do 10 each direction, focus on feeling a stretch in the front and outside of the ankle.
2) Calf Stretch - 20 seconds
3) Dorsiflexion push - do 12, keep your heel on the floor and push your knee forward alternating between inside big toe, middle toe, outside pinky toe. ( Do all 1-3 right leg, then 1-3 left leg)
4) Hamstring Stretch - hold 20seconds - keep hips squared and down foot pointing forward. Reach for for foot with the opposite hand.
5) IT band Stretch - hold 20 seconds- This looks very similar to the hamstring stretch, with the opposite hand reach to the outside of your shin and lean forward slightly.
6) Hip flexor Stretch - hold 20 seconds - Focus on firing you glutes on the back leg. Both the torso rotation and overhead reach are great options. If you plan to sprint or run hills this stretch is very important, both before and after you run.
7) Lateral leg swings - do 10 each leg -Swings should feel light and loose, not forced. Range of motion with increase through out the set. Keep hips squared and your down foot flat and pointing forward. ( My foot is shifting more that I'd like in the video) You will get some added ankle mobility in the transverse plane by keeping your foot forward and still.
8) Forward / Backward leg swings - do 10 each leg - Focus on keeping your torso tall and abs tight. Don't bend forward or arch your back. This gives you true range though the hips and engages truck stability in a similar fashion to running.
This circuit will take about 5 minutes - your run will thank you for it!
Have fun and have and awesome day!!!

Thursday Throwdown!
Add this total body ladder to the end of any workout! You can use DBs or body weight only. This is awesome for an extra fat burning hit to start or finish your day!
Program Rx -
Do 3 moves in 10-1 format
10 of each.. 9 of each... 1 of each
As fast as possible (with proper form 😉) 1) Squat Jump
2) Hollow pull over toe touch
3) Plyo Push up
Coaching Cues
* keep your shoulders back and down on the jumps. Think about pulling the DBs back towards your hips as you jump by creating tension with you upper back, lats and triceps. This will hold your torso in better position and work postural muscles in your upper back. * Abs - Control the motion in both direction. Keep you lower back pressed against the floor, especially as you bring arms over head. Lower your arms and legs only as far as you can with your low back on the floor. * Squeeze abs and glutes in the plyo push ups * Modifications - use only body weight, air squats instead of jumps, regular push ups instead of plyo.
I used 25lb DBs and got 10-1 in 8:58 min.
Have fun with this and have an awesome day!

DOUBLE TROUBLE
Watch out! Here are 2 workouts using a 2KB clean and front squat with a pull up.
METABOLIC EMOM
Clean and Squat / Jump to Pull Up (First and second video)

EMOMs can deliver a serious metabolic hit. This workout is no different. It's a gasser.. your arms, legs and grip will also be challenged. Start with a light to medium bell.
Program Rx
Minute 1 - clean and squat x 5
Minute 2 - Jumping Pull up x 5 (Rest is the time remaining in each minute)

Repeat for 20 min 💪🏻On the jumping pull ups, continue the pull up from the point which you catch the bar, don't fall back into a dead hang and then pull. You can set up a box or step to jump from. 🤕For safety, when jumping from a box, make it high enough that you are holding onto the bar when you jump. Don't let the bar go for the entire 5 reps.

STRENGTH LADDER
Clean and Squat / Strict Pull Up (Third video)
Program Rx
KB clean and squat x 1
Strict pull up x 1
KB clean and squat x 2
Strict pull up x 2
... work up to 5
Rest only as needed between rungs.
Rest 1-2 min between ladders. 💪🏻 Ladders are an awesome way to build strength on the foundation of technique. Starting with lower reps allows you the 'grease the groove' of the movement. Focus of strict technique, especially in the first tree rings when you are fresh. This will carry over into the longer sets. Use a heavier bell than the EMOM set. 💪🏻 Use a band or assisted pull up if needed.
Do each workout once a week for 3 weeks. Take 2-3 days between each. Strength, cardio and physique improvements coming your way!
Have fun and have an awesome night!
